article_title: Middle Management Is the Key to Sustainability
article_source: A People's History of the United States

passage_list.text: A writer in early 1930, boosting the beauty business, started off a magazine article with the sentence: 'The average American woman has sixteen square feet of skin.' He went on to say that there were forty thousand beauty shops in the country, and that $2 billion was spent each year on cosmetics for women-but this was insufficient: 'American women are not yet spending even one-fifth of the amount necessary to improve their appearance.' He then gave an itemized list of the 'annual beauty needs of every woman': twelve hot-oil treatments, fifty-two facials, twenty-six eyebrow plucks, etc.

It seems that women have best been able to make their first escape from the prison of wifeliness, motherhood, femininity, housework, beautification, isolation, when their services have been desperately needed-whether in industry, or in war, or in social movements. Each time practicality pulled the woman out of her prison-in a kind of work-parole program-the attempt was made to push her back once the need was over, and this led to women's struggle for change.

World War II had brought more women than ever before out of the home into work. By 1960, 36 percent of all women sixteen and older- 23 million women-worked for paid wages. But although 43 percent of women with school-age children worked, there were nursery schools for only 2 percent-the rest had to work things out themselves. Women were 50 percent of the voters-but (even by 1967) they held 4 percent of the state legislative seats, and 2 percent of the judgeships. The median income of the working woman was about one-third that of the man. And attitudes toward women did not seem to have changed much since the twenties.

In the civil rights movement of the sixties, the signs of a collective stirring began to appear. Women took the place they customarily took in social movements, in the front lines-as privates, not generals. In the office of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in Atlanta, a Spelman College student named Ruby Doris Smith, who had been jailed during the sit-ins, expressed their anger at the way women were relegated to the routine office work, and she was joined in her protest by two white women in SNCC, Sandra Hayden and Mary King. The men in SNCC listened to them respectfully, read the position paper they had put together asserting their rights, but did not do very much. Ella Baker, a veteran fighter from Harlem, now organizing in the South, knew the pattern: 'I knew from the beginning that as a woman, an older woman in a group of ministers who are accustomed to having women largely as supporters, there was no place for me to have come into a leadership role.'

questions.question: What is the main idea of the first passage?

options.A: The beauty industry's influence on women
options.B: The financial burden of beauty treatments
options.C: The societal expectations of women's appearance
options.D: The history of beauty shops in America

questions.explanation: The passage focuses on societal expectations regarding women's appearance and the beauty industry's role in perpetuating these standards.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the overarching theme of the passage rather than specific details.

questions.question: As used in the passage, the phrase 'work-parole program' most likely refers to:

options.A: A system of temporary employment for women
options.B: A government initiative to reduce unemployment
options.C: A method of reintegrating prisoners into society
options.D: A program to improve workplace conditions

questions.explanation: The phrase 'work-parole program' metaphorically describes how women were temporarily allowed to work outside the home during times of need, only to be pushed back afterward.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for metaphorical language and consider the context in which it is used.

questions.question: Which choice best supports the claim that women's progress in the workforce was limited in the 1960s?

options.A: By 1960, 36 percent of all women sixteen and older worked for paid wages.
options.B: Women were 50 percent of the voters but held only 4 percent of state legislative seats.
options.C: The median income of the working woman was about one-third that of the man.
options.D: Attitudes toward women did not seem to have changed much since the twenties.

questions.explanation: The disparity between women's voting power and their representation in legislative seats highlights the limited progress in achieving gender equality.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Choose evidence that directly supports the claim and reflects the broader implications of the data.

questions.question: The author mentions Ella Baker primarily to:

options.A: Highlight her leadership in the civil rights movement
options.B: Illustrate the challenges faced by women in leadership roles
options.C: Emphasize the importance of grassroots organizing
options.D: Show the generational divide among activists

questions.explanation: Ella Baker's experience exemplifies the systemic barriers women faced in attaining leadership positions, even within progressive movements.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the author's purpose in including specific examples or anecdotes.

questions.question: Which choice best describes the relationship between Ruby Doris Smith and Ella Baker?

options.A: Both were leaders who challenged gender norms in their respective movements.
options.B: Both focused on improving working conditions for women.
options.C: Both were primarily involved in organizing protests.

questions.explanation: Both women challenged traditional gender roles and sought greater recognition and leadership opportunities for women in social movements.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Synthesize information from different parts of the passage to understand relationships between individuals or ideas.

questions.question: Based on the passage, it can be inferred that the author believes:

options.A: Women's economic contributions were undervalued in the 1960s.
options.B: The civil rights movement failed to address gender inequality.
options.C: Women's participation in the workforce declined after World War II.
options.D: Men were largely supportive of women's rights in the 1960s.

questions.explanation: The passage highlights the disparity in income and representation, suggesting that women's economic contributions were not fully recognized or valued.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Draw inferences based on implicit evidence and the author's tone.

questions.question: Which idea from the second passage is most closely related to the challenges described in the fourth passage?

options.A: The temporary nature of women's opportunities
options.B: The importance of social movements in driving change
options.C: The role of practicality in shaping women's roles
options.D: The struggle for leadership roles in male-dominated spaces

questions.explanation: Both passages discuss the challenges women faced in achieving leadership roles, whether in the workforce or social movements.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for thematic connections between different parts of the text.

questions.question: Which choice best completes the sentence? 'American women are not yet spending even one-fifth of the amount necessary to improve their appearance, ______.'
questions.explanation: The phrase 'according to the writer' logically completes the sentence by attributing the statement to the author of the article.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure that the completed sentence maintains grammatical coherence and logical flow.

questions.question: Which choice best completes the sentence? 'Women were 50 percent of the voters, ______ they held only 4 percent of the state legislative seats.'
questions.explanation: The word 'however' correctly signals the contrast between women's voting power and their lack of representation in legislative seats.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use transition words that accurately reflect the relationship between ideas.

questions.question: Based on the data in the passage, what percentage of women with school-age children worked in 1960?
questions.explanation: The passage states that 43 percent of women with school-age children worked in 1960.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay close attention to numerical data and ensure you select the correct figure.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and reasoning. They can interpret complex texts, make nuanced inferences, and connect ideas across passages.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis. They can identify main ideas and details but may miss subtler implications or connections.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning, analyze complex text structures, or synthesize information across passages.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas, details, and the author's purpose.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit information in the text, such as central ideas or straightforward data.
